Interactions with water as a shared resource
column13: Each of our operating mines has a Water Management Plan approved by the regulator and sets approval conditions for water quality management and monitoring. The Group Manager of Water and Property is responsible for implementing the strategy.
column20: Water Management Plan, Water Recycling, Operating mines

column6: Interactions with water as a shared resource
column13: We employ initiatives that minimise operational impacts during high rainfall while maintaining compliant water management. The measures implemented during the year to manage excess water included increased dust suppression, irrigation, discharge treatment, and mechanical evaporator employment.
column20: Rainwater, Water Management, Impact

column6: Interactions with water as a shared resource
column13: This year saw significant improvements in our water management systems, including the decommissioning of dams and the re-establishment of a natural drainage line at Maules Creek by an enforceable undertaking, the installation of evaporation fans at Narrabri and Tarrawonga to manage excess water accumulated from a period of record rainfall, and construction of a new 400 ML brine dam at Narrabri.
column20: Water Management, Improvements, Initiatives

column13: We look to recycle water where we can. The prime operational area for water recycling is the CHPPs, where about 70% of water is recycled. It equates to 35% of total water use.
column20: Water Recycling, CHPPs, Water used

column13: Where possible, our water is also beneficially reused. The Werris Creek Mine has an 18-hectare pivot irrigation system used by a local farmer, with 56 ML used to irrigate crops in FY23.
column20: Water Beneficially Reused, Irrigation System, Werris Creek Mine

column13: When licensed water allocations are not used in our operations, we can trade these for irrigation purposes. About 2,800 ML was traded to local farmers.
column20: Water Allocation, Trading, Operations

column7: During the year, 9,569 megalitres (ML) of water were withdrawn, of which 22% came from water allocation licences, with the remainder from surface water run-off.

column6: Operational sites owned, leased, managed in, or adjacent to, protected areas and areas of high biodiversity value outside protected areas
column13: Independent subject matter experts undertake environmental assessments. Their advice forms the basis of our plans for managing any potential impacts on surface water, groundwater, flora and fauna, Aboriginal cultural heritage, historic heritage, air quality, noise, agriculture and geochemistry.
column20: Environmental Assessments, Risk Management, Biodiversity

column6: Operational sites owned, leased, managed in, or adjacent to, protected areas and areas of high biodiversity value outside protected areas
column13: Enhancing proactive risk management at operations through coaching in critical control monitoring and material risk evaluation for operational compliance. Improving identification of hazards associated with environmental, regulatory and reputational risk.
column20: Proactive Risk Management, Hazard Identification, Biodiversity

column6: Operational sites owned, leased, managed in, or adjacent to, protected areas and areas of high biodiversity value outside protected areas
column13: We continued integrating our compliance requirements into operational processes, fostering regulatory capability and enhancing our environmental management plans. We are also implementing improvements in rehabilitation and disturbance monitoring activities.
column20: Compliance Integration, Regulatory Capability, Biodiversity

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: Biodiversity management plans are in place at each of our operations and consider key risks to threatened, endangered and/or critically endangered species and communities known to occur within offset areas. Approved Whitehaven offset areas are secured in perpetuity, protecting and enhancing biodiversity values, including threatened ecological communities and species.
column20: Biodiversity Management Plans, Offset Areas, Operations

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: We aim to contribute to a diverse local economy by putting to productive use the land owned by Whitehaven but not required for our mining operations or managed for biodiversity. To that end, 48% of Whitehaven's land, equivalent to 41,250 hectares, is leased to local farmers for agricultural activities such as grazing and cropping.
column20: Land Leasing, Agricultural Activities, Biodiversity

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: Over the past six years, we have provided $1.5 million in funding to the Australian National University, the NSW Department of Planning and Environment, and BirdLife Australia to undertake research and share information on the Regent Honeyeater, Swift Parrot and South-eastern Long-eared Bat. This funding is part of the federal conditions of approval for the Maules Creek Mine.
column20: Research Funding, Biodiversity Conservation, Initiatives

column13: We aim to ensure no net loss in biodiversity values through our operations. Where biodiversity impacts cannot be avoided or mitigated, we offset these residual impacts with biodiversity-managed areas such as biodiversity stewardship sites and those under conservation agreements as offsets.
column20: Biodiversity Offsets, Conservation Agreements, Initiatives

column13: We select and incorporate offset areas into our biodiversity estate based on advice from independent subject matter experts. The NSW and Australian governments approve these areas. Approved offsets ensure that like-for-like or better biodiversity values are maintained and conserved.
column20: Offset Areas Incorporation, Government Approval, Biodiversity

column13: We implement feral animal management, fire management, weed management and revegetation programs throughout our biodiversity-managed areas. To monitor our progress and ensure survival rates from tree planting activities are as high as possible, we collect biodiversity management metrics from our fencing, pest animal and weed control activities and assess survey data from our flora and fauna monitoring programs.
column20: Feral Animal Management, Revegetation, Protection

column6: IUCN Red List species and national conversation list species with habitats in areas affected by operations
column8: Investment in Gunnedah's new Koala Sanctuary
column13: Whitehaven has made a significant financial contribution to establishing a new world-class Koala Sanctuary in Gunnedah, which commenced construction in late 2022. The sanctuary will create a new hub of wildlife conservation in North West NSW, attract visitors to the region and create a positive environmental and economic impact for years to come.
column20: Koala Sanctuary contribution, Wildlife conservation, Environmental protection

column13: We prioritise reducing Scope 1 emissions by implementing site-based initiatives where suitable technology abatement solutions are feasible. We will use carbon offsets or credits approved under the scheme Ã¢ÂÂ Australian carbon credit units (ACCUs) and Safeguard Mechanism credits (SMCs) Ã¢ÂÂ where feasible abatement initiatives are not meeting our regulatory emissions reduction obligations under the Safeguard Mechanism.
column20: Scope 1 emissions reduction strategies, Carbon offsets, Environmental stewardship

column13: We offset about 100% of our Scope 2 emissions by purchasing carbon-neutral electricity certified by Climate Active from our electricity supplier and have been doing so since October 2021. To meet Narrabri's Safeguard Mechanism emissions intensity decline rate of 9.5% p.a. to FY30, we will need to purchase carbon offsets approved under the scheme (ACCUs and/or SMCs), with viable solutions not currently available to decrease most of our emissions.
column20: Just transition commitment, Workforce support, Social responsibility

column13: The Paris Agreement requires national plans on climate change to consider the need for a just transition of the workforce and the creation of decent work and quality jobs. The Australian Government has announced the establishment of the Net Zero Authority, which will support workers in emissions-intensive sectors to access new employment, skills and support as the net zero transformation continues. We acknowledge that the low-carbon energy transition must happen reasonably to workforces, communities and consumers.
column20: Safeguard Mechanism explanation, Emissions regulation, Compliance standards

column13: The Safeguard Mechanism applies to extensive industrial facilities that emit more than 100,000 tonnes of CO2-e per year, which includes our Narrabri and Maules Creek mines. From FY24, the reformed scheme requires Safeguard facilities to reduce their 'baseline' emissions intensity by 4.9% p.a. to FY30.
column20: Decarbonisation roadmap, Carbon reduction, Green initiatives

column13: Our decarbonisation roadmap outlines our current and potential site-based levers to reduce our Scope 1 and 2 emissions footprint. This roadmap will evolve as emerging or breakthrough emissions abatement technologies become available and financially feasible and as we complete investigations and explore potential decarbonisation opportunities. In addition, carbon offsets will continue to be an essential part of our Scope 2 abatement efforts. They will be crucial to meet our Scope 1 emissions reduction obligations under the Safeguard Mechanism.
column20: Air quality monitoring, Dust control, Pollution prevention

column6: Nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur oxides (SOx), and other significant air emissions
column13: All our operational sites monitor air quality in real-time. These systems set trigger levels for air quality Ã¢ÂÂ below approved criteria Ã¢ÂÂ to allow us to respond in advance and to ensure criteria levels are not exceeded. We implement approved protocols in response to visual and monitored dust levels.
column20: Waste management practices, Recycling, Environmental sustainability

column6: Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts
column7: Our mine sites generate various types of waste during exploration, construction, operation and closure activities.
